docs.lead_paragraph: THE state senate recently passed a bill to prohibit the state government from contracting with foreigners to perform services. Maryland, Missouri, Wisconsin and Connecticut are contemplating similar legislation. Long on sentiment but short on sense, such bills deprive states of a powerful tool for saving money and undermine their economies. The New Jersey bill materialized after a contractor hired by the state to manage a welfare and food-stamp program moved its customer-service operations to Bombay from Wisconsin to cut costs. The grandstanding began almost immediately.

docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to customer service, consumers give the highest grades to supermarkets and packaged-food companies, a recent survey finds. Eighty-five percent of the 1,010 adults questioned this spring said supermarkets did a good job serving customers. Packaged food companies, with their consumer hot lines and recipes, received a good grade from 75 percent. Rounding out the top five were hospitals, 72 percent; computer hardware companies, 71 percent; and computer software companies, 70 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the Uniondale school district got the news that it was losing $2.6 million in state aid, educators prepared a budget with a proposed tax increase of 7.5 percent. But when $1.7 million was restored to the district at the end of April, the tax increase was reduced by almost 3 percentage points. Varsity tennis and middle-school basketball were among the programs cancelled when the Seaford school district, expecting to lose more than $1 million from the state, cut after-school activities from its budget. But when $648,000 was restored, the district quickly cancelled the cancellations.

headline.main: Budget Sows Confusion in Local Schools

docs.abstract: Article on confusion school districts on Long Island are experiencing as some loss of state aid dictated by budget cuts is restored; school districts weighed program cuts against tax increases and prepared budgets accordingly; state lawmakers, in rare bipartisan alliance, tossed out Gov Pataki's fiscal plan and restored $1.1 billion in education spending; photos (M)
